item.title: Russian air attacks pound Ukraine, killing 3 and knocking out power in most regions

Russia fired more than 650 drones and three dozen missiles at Ukraine in a large-scale attack that began during the night and stretched into daylight hours Tuesday, officials said. At least three people were killed, including a four-year-old child.

item.title: Nigeria: Kontagora’s Christmas gift – the return of its abducted children
item.description:
Diocese of Kontagora’s Catholic Bishop, Bulus Dauwa Yohanna, on Monday confirmed to Vatican News the release of 130 students and staff abducted from St. Mary’s Primary and Secondary School in Papiri on 21 November. The children and staff were part of an original 315 victims forcibly taken by gunmen from the school in the night.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
Diocese of Kontagora’s Catholic Bishop, Bulus Dauwa Yohanna, on Monday confirmed to Vatican News the release of 130 students and staff abducted from St. Mary’s Primary and Secondary School in Papiri on 21 November. The children and staff were part of an original 315 victims forcibly taken by gunmen from the school in the night.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/africa/news/2025-12/nigeria-kontagora-s-christmas-gift-the-return-of-its-abducted.html)

item.title: LIVE: Security Council meets on escalating violence in Sudan
item.description: Senior UN political and humanitarian officials are set brief the Security Council this afternoon as members meet to discuss the rapidly deteriorating situation in Sudan, where intensified fighting – including in the Kordofan region – has driven widespread civilian harm and displacement. The region has seen a sharp escalation, including a deadly drone attack on a UN peacekeeping base that killed six Bangladeshi peacekeepers. The meeting was requested by Sudan and Transitional Prime Minister, Kamil Eltayeb Idris, is expected to attend. Follow live below and UN News app users can click here.
item.source:markdown: Senior UN political and humanitarian officials are set brief the Security Council this afternoon as members meet to discuss the rapidly deteriorating situation in Sudan, where intensified fighting – including in the Kordofan region – has driven widespread civilian harm and displacement. The region has seen a sharp escalation, including a deadly drone attack on a UN peacekeeping base that killed six Bangladeshi peacekeepers. The meeting was requested by Sudan and Transitional Prime Minister, Kamil Eltayeb Idris, is expected to attend. Follow live below and UN News app users can click here.

item.title: 'Family kept me going' - Irish woman after ICE detention
item.description: Irish citizen Donna Hughes-Brown, who had been held by immigration authorities in the US for almost five months, has said it is fabulous to be free but she is still feeling a bit overwhelmed since her release last week.

item.title: Russian general killed in car bomb in Moscow, investigators say
item.description: A car bomb killed a Russian general on Monday, the third such killing of a senior military officer in just over a year. Investigators said Ukraine may be behind the attack.

![A white car in a parking lot is shown with its left door blown out and other parts severely damaged.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/31f81fc5-eee5-46a0-91f8-330242056ee5,1766392984009/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C2560%2C1440%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
A car bomb killed a Russian general on Monday, the third such killing of a senior military officer in just over a year. Investigators said Ukraine may be behind the attack.

item.title: 'It's like Groundhog Day': Waiting decades for justice in India's overburdened court system
item.description: India's archaic judicial system and its backlog of millions of cases leave those seeking justice, along with many lawyers and judges, with a sense of hopelessness.

item.title: President calls for kindness in first Christmas message
item.description: The President of Ireland Catherine Connolly has used her first Christmas message to encourage people to reflect "on the values that truly matter: kindness, tolerance, respect for each other's differences, and to reflect on how we may nurture our shared humanity".

item.title: Sudan drone attack on Darfur market kills 10: rescuers
item.description: A drone attack on a busy market in Sudan's North Darfur state killed 10 people over the weekend, first responders said, without saying who was responsible.

item.title: Trump administration denies cover-up over Epstein files
item.description: US Justice Department officials denied redacting the Epstein files to protect President Donald Trump as criticism mounted over the partial and heavily censored release of documents.

item.title: Nigerian authorities secure release of abducted students
item.description: Nigerian authorities have secured the release of 130 kidnapped schoolchildren taken by gunmen from a Catholic school in November, a presidential spokesman said, after 100 were freed earlier this month.
item.source:markdown: Nigerian authorities have secured the release of 130 kidnapped schoolchildren taken by gunmen from a Catholic school in November, a presidential spokesman said, after 100 were freed earlier this month.

item.title: Nigeria says remaining 130 abducted students have now been released
item.description: The students are among more than 300 pupils and 12 staff seized by gunmen from St Mary's Catholic boarding school in the village of Papiri in the early hours of Nov. 21.

item.title: Pizzeria staffed by those on autism spectrum thrives in Italy
item.description: An autism diagnosis for his son motivated Nico Acampora in Italy to open a restaurant staffed only by those on the autism spectrum. Everything in PizzAut is also designed to provide a sensory friendly experience and it's become a tremendous success.
item.source:markdown:
![A man passes a pizza to a table of people. ](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/0183d2a9-17d1-498c-a769-8a1cb9db6e33,1766344177601/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1920%2C1080%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)

item.title: Zanzibar Cup 2026 aims to build on global fraternity and peace
item.description:
The fifth edition of the international kitesurfing event is set to take place on 7 February 2026 in Zanzibar, Tanzania, with the deadline for participation on 6 January. The competition aims to build on social, cultural, and humanitarian dimensions that convey a strong message of peace and fellowship, in addition to good sportsmanship and an exciting race in a stunningly beautiful part of the world.

Read all

item.title: Pope Leo XIV: May all children of the world live in peace!
item.description:
Reflecting on the figure of Saint Joseph on the Fourth Sunday of Advent, Pope Leo XIV recalls the virtues he lived of piety, charity, and mercy that educate the heart to encounter Christ and our brothers and sisters. As we await the birth of the Saviour, he encourages us to be "a welcoming manger, a hospitable home, a sign of God’s presence" and that all children may live in peace.

Read all

item.title: Ukraine President sceptical over trilateral peace talks amid deadly clashes
item.description:
Ukraine's president says the United States has proposed a format for peace talks that would place Ukraine and Russia at the same table, but he doubts such a meeting would bring real progress. Zelenskyy spoke as a Russian missile strike on port infrastructure in Odesa in southern Ukraine killed at least eight people and wounded twenty-seven, while Ukrainian drones hit several Russian targets.

Read all

item.description: "It's a diplomatic dance" - from brawling delegates to impossible demands, Michael Browne from Limerick City has seen it all in his two decades in security at the UN in New York. Now as he retires, he reflects on some heart-stopping moments and ponders a fast-changing security landscape.

item.title: Somalis say foreign ships are stealing their fish, and it's fuelling a piracy resurgence
item.description: Piracy off the coast of Somalia is back in the headlines after European Union naval forces seized an Iranian fishing vessel last month that Somali pirates used to briefly hijack a Malta-flagged tanker carrying gasoline from India to South Africa. Fishermen insist the bigger problem in the region is that foreign vessels are fishing in waters intended for locals, harming their livelihoods.
item.source:markdown:
![A man stands on a rock by the ocean with a fishing rod.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/1e16f609-965b-4a97-9bbf-37b75dc54675,1765951344335/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C221%2C5500%2C3093%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Piracy off the coast of Somalia is back in the headlines after European Union naval forces seized an Iranian fishing vessel last month that Somali pirates used to briefly hijack a Malta-flagged tanker carrying gasoline from India to South Africa. Fishermen insist the bigger problem in the region is that foreign vessels are fishing in waters intended for locals, harming their livelihoods.

item.title: Canada's growing profile in Antarctic research may get a boost with expedition in 2026
item.description: Canada's growing profile in Antarctic research may get another boost in early 2026, as the commander of the Royal Canadian Navy confirms a possible second expedition is in the works, in collaboration with the Chilean navy. Climate scientists from the first all-Canadian expedition in March hope it offers the chance to collect more samples, as preliminary results come in from the earlier research mission.

Canada's growing profile in Antarctic research may get another boost in early 2026, as the commander of the Royal Canadian Navy confirms a possible second expedition is in the works, in collaboration with the Chilean navy. Climate scientists from the first all-Canadian expedition in March hope it offers the chance to collect more samples, as preliminary results come in from the earlier research mission.

item.title: More than 70 Islamic State targets struck by US in Syria
item.description: US forces struck more than 70 Islamic State group targets in Syria in what President Donald Trump described as "very serious retaliation" for an attack that killed three Americans last weekend.
item.source:markdown: US forces struck more than 70 Islamic State group targets in Syria in what President Donald Trump described as "very serious retaliation" for an attack that killed three Americans last weekend.

item.title: UK complicit in citizens' murder during Troubles - Burns
item.description: GAA President Jarlath Burns said that during the Troubles the people of South Armagh feared the night because of rogue police officers and soldiers working with loyalist paramilitaries.

item.title: Taoiseach presses Lebanon on justice for Seán Rooney
item.description: Taoiseach Micheál Martin has said that he has expressed the Irish Government's "annoyance and anger" at the slow pace of the justice system in dealing with those responsible for the death of Private Seán Rooney.
item.source:markdown: Taoiseach Micheál Martin has said that he has expressed the Irish Government's "annoyance and anger" at the slow pace of the justice system in dealing with those responsible for the death of Private Seán Rooney.

item.title: US Justice Department releases new cache of Epstein files
item.description: The US Justice Department has released more than 300,000 pages of records from its investigations into the late financier and convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, bowing to pressure from politicians who forced their ⁠disclosure with a new law.
item.source:markdown: The US Justice Department has released more than 300,000 pages of records from its investigations into the late financier and convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, bowing to pressure from politicians who forced their ⁠disclosure with a new law.

item.description: The GAA has opted to maintain its relationship with Allianz despite calls from a number of county boards to end its association with the insurance group.
item.source:markdown: The GAA has opted to maintain its relationship with Allianz despite calls from a number of county boards to end its association with the insurance group.

item.title: Why a U.S. ground invasion of Venezuela would be a disaster | About That
item.description: Tensions between the United States and Venezuela are escalating as the U.S. continues to strike alleged Venezuelan drug-trafficking boats and signals the possibility of a ground invasion. item.title: Woman would be alive if partner was listened to - family
item.description: The family of a woman killed by her partner while he was suffering a relapse of a schizoaffective disorder have said they believe she would be alive today if her partner had been properly listened to.

item.title: Pasolini: May the Church foster encounter as she sets out to know God
item.description:
“The universality of salvation: A hope without conditions” is the theme of the third Advent meditation, delivered Friday morning in the Paul VI Hall in the presence of the Pope. In his sermon, Fr Roberto Pasolini, the Preacher of the Papal Household focuses on the attitude of the Magi, who boldly dared to open themselves to the unknown.

Read all

item.title: Man jailed for life for 'brutal' murder of brother-in-law
item.description: A 44-year-old man who shot dead his brother-in-law with a submachine gun in the front garden of the victim's home in Ballyfermot, west Dublin, almost four years ago has been sentenced to life in prison.
item.source:markdown: A 44-year-old man who shot dead his brother-in-law with a submachine gun in the front garden of the victim's home in Ballyfermot, west Dublin, almost four years ago has been sentenced to life in prison.

item.title: Gaza no longer has famine, says global hunger monitor
item.description: There is no longer famine in Gaza, a global hunger monitor has said, after access for humanitarian and commercial food deliveries improved following a fragile 10 October ceasefire in the war between Israel and Palestinian militants Hamas.
item.source:markdown: There is no longer famine in Gaza, a global hunger monitor has said, after access for humanitarian and commercial food deliveries improved following a fragile 10 October ceasefire in the war between Israel and Palestinian militants Hamas.

item.title: Ukraine says it has struck Russian 'shadow fleet' tanker
item.description: Ukraine said it has hit a Russian "shadow fleet" tanker with aerial drones in neutral waters of the Mediterranean Sea, its first strike in the sea in the nearly four-year war.
item.source:markdown: Ukraine said it has hit a Russian "shadow fleet" tanker with aerial drones in neutral waters of the Mediterranean Sea, its first strike in the sea in the nearly four-year war.

item.title: Sudan war: Kordofan’s El-Obeid ‘one or two steps’ away from being attacked
item.description: As fighting escalates in Sudan, “people are scared, people are fleeing their homes”, the UN migration agency, IOM, said on Friday, noting that more than 50,000 people have been uprooted since late October in the Kordofans region alone.
item.source:markdown: As fighting escalates in Sudan, “people are scared, people are fleeing their homes”, the UN migration agency, IOM, said on Friday, noting that more than 50,000 people have been uprooted since late October in the Kordofans region alone.

item.title: South Sudan: UN condemns killing of staff member in Wau, calls for swift investigation
item.description: The United Nations on Friday condemned the killing of a civilian staff member serving with its peacekeeping mission in South Sudan (UNMISS), calling on the authorities to swiftly bring those responsible to justice.
item.source:markdown: The United Nations on Friday condemned the killing of a civilian staff member serving with its peacekeeping mission in South Sudan (UNMISS), calling on the authorities to swiftly bring those responsible to justice.

item.title: Gaza famine pushed back, but millions still face hunger and malnutrition, UN says
item.description: Food security in Gaza has improved since the ceasefire declared in October, pushing back famine conditions, but the situation remains critical with more than three-quarters of the population still facing acute hunger and malnutrition, a new UN-backed analysis has found.
item.source:markdown: Food security in Gaza has improved since the ceasefire declared in October, pushing back famine conditions, but the situation remains critical with more than three-quarters of the population still facing acute hunger and malnutrition, a new UN-backed analysis has found.

item.title: UN urges calm in Bangladesh after killing of protest leader sparks unrest
item.description: The United Nations has urged calm in Bangladesh after the killing of a prominent youth protest leader sparked fresh unrest, raising concerns about political violence and the safety of civic space as the country prepares for elections early next year.
item.source:markdown: The United Nations has urged calm in Bangladesh after the killing of a prominent youth protest leader sparked fresh unrest, raising concerns about political violence and the safety of civic space as the country prepares for elections early next year.

item.title: World News in Brief: More UN staff detentions in Yemen, peacekeepers killed in Sudan sent home, attacks in Ukraine
item.description: The UN Secretary-General on Friday condemned the arbitrary detention of 10 more UN personnel by Houthi de facto authorities in Yemen, warning that the growing crackdown is crippling humanitarian operations and putting millions of lives at risk.
item.source:markdown: The UN Secretary-General on Friday condemned the arbitrary detention of 10 more UN personnel by Houthi de facto authorities in Yemen, warning that the growing crackdown is crippling humanitarian operations and putting millions of lives at risk.

item.title: Security Council renews DR Congo peacekeeping mission amid renewed M23 offensives in the east
item.description: The UN Security Council on Friday unanimously extended the mandate of the UN peacekeeping mission in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) for another year, as fighting in the country’s east intensified amid renewed offensives by the M23 rebel group.
item.source:markdown: The UN Security Council on Friday unanimously extended the mandate of the UN peacekeeping mission in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) for another year, as fighting in the country’s east intensified amid renewed offensives by the M23 rebel group.

item.title: Security Council hears of fading election prospects in Libya
item.description: The path to long-awaited elections in Libya is paved with complications but they can be overcome, the UN Special Representative for the country said on Friday in a briefing to the Security Council.
item.source:markdown: The path to long-awaited elections in Libya is paved with complications but they can be overcome, the UN Special Representative for the country said on Friday in a briefing to the Security Council.

item.title: Israel could be bringing back the death penalty — but only for Palestinians
item.description: While any debate over imposing the death penalty is bound to be emotional and contentious, Israel’s proposal to impose lethal punishment only on Palestinians makes new legislation before the Knesset especially egregious, say rights groups. One called it a "celebration of death and revenge."
item.source:markdown:
![A close up of the noose lapel pin worn by far right members of the Israeli Knesset to hearings on the proposed death penalty bill.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/4bd09f43-552d-42ff-b31e-202fb4b7eafd,1766107194926/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C592%2C1536%2C864%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
While any debate over imposing the death penalty is bound to be emotional and contentious, Israel’s proposal to impose lethal punishment only on Palestinians makes new legislation before the Knesset especially egregious, say rights groups. One called it a "celebration of death and revenge."

item.title: Argentinian layman, 11 Spanish martyrs to be beatified
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV authorises the promulgation of decrees relating to the upcoming beatification of nine seminarians, a priest, and a layman, martyrs during the Spanish Civil War; as well as an Argentine family man, Enrique Ernesto Shaw, an entrepreneur involved in various ecclesial works. As of today, Fra Berardo Atonna and Sister Domenica Caterina dello Spirito Santo, both Italian, and Joseph Panjikaran, an Indian priest, are recognized as venerable.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
Pope Leo XIV authorises the promulgation of decrees relating to the upcoming beatification of nine seminarians, a priest, and a layman, martyrs during the Spanish Civil War; as well as an Argentine family man, Enrique Ernesto Shaw, an entrepreneur involved in various ecclesial works. As of today, Fra Berardo Atonna and Sister Domenica Caterina dello Spirito Santo, both Italian, and Joseph Panjikaran, an Indian priest, are recognized as venerable.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/pope/news/2025-12/argentinian-layman-11-spanish-martyrs-to-be-beatified.html)

item.title: EU finds more money for Ukraine, but fails to reach deal to release frozen Russian assets
item.description: European Union leaders have decided to borrow cash to loan 90 billion euros ($145 billion Cdn) to Ukraine to fund its defence against Russia for the next two years rather than use frozen Russian assets, sidestepping divisions over an unprecedented plan to finance Kyiv with Russian sovereign cash.

European Union leaders have decided to borrow cash to loan 90 billion euros ($145 billion Cdn) to Ukraine to fund its defence against Russia for the next two years rather than use frozen Russian assets, sidestepping divisions over an unprecedented plan to finance Kyiv with Russian sovereign cash.

item.title: Gaza: Access to food improves but living conditions remain dire

item.title: How Venezuelan crude could shake things up for Canadian producers
item.description: Venezuela's bitumen-heavy oil is virtually identical to Canada's and the South American country has the largest proven reserves in the world. But Venezuelan oil has essentially disappeared from world markets over the past 20 years. U.S. President Donald Trump's threats to invade Venezuela have opened up the prospect that it could one day return, with huge implications for Canada.
item.source:markdown:
![A pair of pumpjacks are bisected by a rainbow.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/72155439-8df1-4fcb-964f-3701acfbc1c7,1766070648146/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C78%2C2000%2C1125%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Venezuela's bitumen-heavy oil is virtually identical to Canada's and the South American country has the largest proven reserves in the world. But Venezuelan oil has essentially disappeared from world markets over the past 20 years. U.S. President Donald Trump's threats to invade Venezuela have opened up the prospect that it could one day return, with huge implications for Canada.

item.description: A French court has sentenced a doctor to life in jail for poisoning 30 child and adult patients, 12 of whom died, reportedly in an attempt to discredit co-workers.

item.title: Pope Leo calls for an unarmed peace amid the threat of war
item.description:
In his Message for the 2026 World Day of Peace, Pope Leo XIV addresses the escalation of war, rearmament and fear in international relations, and reiterates the Church’s opposition to deterrence based on military force. He calls for disarmament, dialogue and the conversion of hearts as necessary conditions for a lasting and unarmed peace.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
In his Message for the 2026 World Day of Peace, Pope Leo XIV addresses the escalation of war, rearmament and fear in international relations, and reiterates the Church’s opposition to deterrence based on military force. He calls for disarmament, dialogue and the conversion of hearts as necessary conditions for a lasting and unarmed peace.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/pope/news/2025-12/pope-peace-day-message-leo-unarmed-disarmed.html)

item.title: Man found not guilty of murder by reason of insanity
item.description: A 53-year-old man who was suffering from a severe relapse of schizoaffective disorder when he killed his girlfriend has been found not guilty of her murder by reason of insanity.

item.title: Ukraine suffering continues as electricity is cut for days amid ongoing Russian attacks

item.title: Nigeria: OLA Sisters plead for global help as 165 students and staff remain in captivity
item.description:
The Sisters of Our Lady of Apostles (OLA) have made a further appeal to the Global Community to come to the aid of the 165 learners and staff of St. Mary’s Catholic Primary and Secondary Schools in Papiri, Nigeria, who have been in captivity for the fourth week since their abduction on 21 November.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
The Sisters of Our Lady of Apostles (OLA) have made a further appeal to the Global Community to come to the aid of the 165 learners and staff of St. Mary’s Catholic Primary and Secondary Schools in Papiri, Nigeria, who have been in captivity for the fourth week since their abduction on 21 November.

item.title: Why is the U.K. rethinking puberty blockers?
item.description: Today, an in-depth look at puberty blockers and their use on minors with gender dysphoria. These drugs have come under an enormous amount of scrutiny in recent years, with some questioning their benefits, safety and long-term impact. After banning the use of puberty blockers for gender treatment of people under 18, a new clinical trial in the U.K. aims to get to the bottom of those concerns. Azeen Ghorayshi is a science and gender reporter for the New York Times. She’ll parse through what we know and don’t know about the effects of blockers in minors, how this became a hugely divisive and politicized debate around the world, and whether this new trial could change our understanding. For transcripts of Front Burner, please visit: https://www.cbc.ca/radio/frontburner/transcripts [https://www.cbc.ca/radio/frontburner/transcripts]
item.source:markdown:
![Abstract image of a burner on a stove](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/b160fe9c-f2a8-490b-a969-72f55ff4bd73,1760988313788/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1920%2C1080%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Today, an in-depth look at puberty blockers and their use on minors with gender dysphoria. These drugs have come under an enormous amount of scrutiny in recent years, with some questioning their benefits, safety and long-term impact. After banning the use of puberty blockers for gender treatment of people under 18, a new clinical trial in the U.K. aims to get to the bottom of those concerns. Azeen Ghorayshi is a science and gender reporter for the New York Times. She’ll parse through what we know and don’t know about the effects of blockers in minors, how this became a hugely divisive and politicized debate around the world, and whether this new trial could change our understanding. For transcripts of Front Burner, please visit: https://www.cbc.ca/radio/frontburner/transcripts \[https://www.cbc.ca/radio/frontburner/transcripts\]

item.description:

item.title: Living Ancestors:’ Voices of African Sisters are a testament of resilience
item.description:
Countless stories of courage go untold, but the book “Living Ancestors” emerges as a voice for the unseen, the unheard and the deeply faithful women who have shape Africa’s spiritual and social spaces through decades of consecrated service. This ground-breaking work has been brought to life by Sr. Mumbi Kigutha of the Sister of the Precious blood Dayton, Ohio, CPPS, offers a rare glimpse into their lived experiences.

item.title: Pope Leo: Flowers can bloom even in prisons
item.description:
During his homily on the Sunday of the Jubilee of Prisoners, Pope Leo XIV challenges both inmates and those responsible for the prisons to hold on to hope and he reminds everyone “that no human being is defined only by his or her actions and that justice is always a process of reparation and reconciliation.”

Read all
item.source:markdown:
During his homily on the Sunday of the Jubilee of Prisoners, Pope Leo XIV challenges both inmates and those responsible for the prisons to hold on to hope and he reminds everyone “that no human being is defined only by his or her actions and that justice is always a process of reparation and reconciliation.”

item.title: Challenging period ahead as flu season gathers pace
item.description: Ireland has experienced bad influenza seasons before, and the weeks ahead are shaping up to offer a testing season of festive flu and colds. item.title: A year of 'dramatic highs and lows': 2025's 'roller-coaster ride' for the Royals
item.description: In the annals of Royal Family history, 2025 will be remembered as the year the monarch took the virtually unprecedented step of stripping his younger brother of his titles and honours. But as much as the scandal surrounding the former prince now known only as Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor garnered headlines, there were other notable moments this year that sent signals about the monarchy and its future.

item.title: Cambodia: In the midst of conflict, the youth call for peace
item.description:

item.title: Will ‘Trump Accounts’ make U.S. kids $1 million by age 28? | About That
item.description: American babies born during U.S. President Donald Trump's second term are set to receive $1,000: a gift of seed money that the government says — if contributed to maximally — will yield a return of more than $1 million by the time those children turn 28. Andrew Chang does the math to calculate the extent to which this could actually be possible and fact-checks the claim that Trump Accounts will 'jumpstart the American dream.' Images provided by The Canadian Press, Reuters and Getty Images
item.source:markdown:
![U.S. President Donald Trump.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/47666c44-fcca-423d-acba-0c12e27cee1b,1765578779687/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1920%2C1080%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
American babies born during U.S. President Donald Trump's second term are set to receive $1,000: a gift of seed money that the government says — if contributed to maximally — will yield a return of more than $1 million by the time those children turn 28. Andrew Chang does the math to calculate the extent to which this could actually be possible and fact-checks the claim that Trump Accounts will 'jumpstart the American dream.'
Images provided by The Canadian Press, Reuters and Getty Images

item.title: Sherrone Moore charged with stalking, home invasion after being fired as Michigan football coach
item.description: Sherrone Moore, who was abruptly fired this week as the University of Michigan football coach, was charged Friday with three crimes including home invasion and stalking a person he had dated, prosecutors said.
item.source:markdown:

Sherrone Moore, who was abruptly fired this week as the University of Michigan football coach, was charged Friday with three crimes including home invasion and stalking a person he had dated, prosecutors said.

item.title: EU agrees €3 small parcel tax on goods from outside bloc
item.description: EU finance ministers have agreed to impose a €3 duty on all small parcels imported into the bloc starting 1 July next year, to help tackle a flood of cheap imports by the likes of Shein and Temu.
item.source:markdown: EU finance ministers have agreed to impose a €3 duty on all small parcels imported into the bloc starting 1 July next year, to help tackle a flood of cheap imports by the likes of Shein and Temu.

item.title: Security Council LIVE: Ambassadors debate deepening crisis in eastern DR Congo
item.description: The UN Security Council meet this morning in New York to discuss the rapidly deteriorating situation in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), amid intensified fighting and mass displacement. The UN Peacekeeping chief briefed on recent peace efforts – including the Washington Accords between the DRC and Rwanda, signed just days before violence surged again – heightening fears of a worsening humanitarian emergency and regional spillover. Follow live below and UN News app users can click here. Find our recent reporting here on the crisis and go here for all our in-depth meeting coverage.
item.source:markdown: The UN Security Council meet this morning in New York to discuss the rapidly deteriorating situation in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), amid intensified fighting and mass displacement. The UN Peacekeeping chief briefed on recent peace efforts – including the Washington Accords between the DRC and Rwanda, signed just days before violence surged again – heightening fears of a worsening humanitarian emergency and regional spillover. Follow live below and UN News app users can click here. Find our recent reporting here on the crisis and go here for all our in-depth meeting coverage.

item.title: Sudan war: Aid teams say deal struck to reach stricken El Fasher
item.description: In Sudan, deep concerns persist for the many tens of thousands of people believed to still be trapped in El Fasher in the Darfur region, but UN aid agencies believe they may soon get access to the embattled city.
item.source:markdown: In Sudan, deep concerns persist for the many tens of thousands of people believed to still be trapped in El Fasher in the Darfur region, but UN aid agencies believe they may soon get access to the embattled city.

item.title: UN sounds alarm over rising demands on water resources as scarcity increases
item.description: Pressure on freshwater resources is growing as demand increases in regions marked by scarcity, the UN Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) said in a report published on Friday.
item.source:markdown: Pressure on freshwater resources is growing as demand increases in regions marked by scarcity, the UN Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) said in a report published on Friday.

item.title: UN mission’s exit marks milestone in Iraq’s post-conflict transition
item.description: After more than two decades working alongside Iraq through war, political upheaval and the fight against ISIL terrorists, the UN Assistance Mission there (UNAMI) ends its mandate on 31 December – a closure its top official describes as “honourable, dignified, and earned”.
item.source:markdown: After more than two decades working alongside Iraq through war, political upheaval and the fight against ISIL terrorists, the UN Assistance Mission there (UNAMI) ends its mandate on 31 December – a closure its top official describes as “honourable, dignified, and earned”.

item.title: From mud homes to joyful songs: Living heritage on the global stage
item.description: Drums and celebration filled a hall in New Delhi, India, as communities from across the world saw their traditions recognised, from Panama’s Quincha homes built by collective hands, to Yemen’s Hadrami Dan gatherings where poetry and music are created in the moment.
item.source:markdown: Drums and celebration filled a hall in New Delhi, India, as communities from across the world saw their traditions recognised, from Panama’s Quincha homes built by collective hands, to Yemen’s Hadrami Dan gatherings where poetry and music are created in the moment.

item.title: Peace falters as fighting in eastern DR Congo raises fears of regional war
item.description: Civilians across eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) are facing collapsing health services and mass displacement as fighting spreads, undermining recent peace efforts and raising fears of a wider regional crisis.
item.source:markdown: Civilians across eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) are facing collapsing health services and mass displacement as fighting spreads, undermining recent peace efforts and raising fears of a wider regional crisis.

item.title: UN environment assembly wraps up in Nairobi
item.description: The seventh session of the United Nations Environment Assembly (UNEA-7) concluded in Nairobi, Kenya, on Friday with Member States adopting 11 resolutions, three decisions and a ministerial declaration aiming to advance solutions for a more resilient planet.
item.source:markdown: The seventh session of the United Nations Environment Assembly (UNEA-7) concluded in Nairobi, Kenya, on Friday with Member States adopting 11 resolutions, three decisions and a ministerial declaration aiming to advance solutions for a more resilient planet.

item.title: Venezuela vexes Trump but rightward trend across Americas could help U.S. national security strategy
item.description: The favourite in Chile's election on Sunday is the right-wing José Antonio Kast. A Kast victory would be the latest rightward political shift in South America, as U.S. President Donald Trump and the White House try to coax or force the socialist leader of Venezuela from office.

item.title: Maestro Riccardo Muti set to conduct concert in Vatican
item.description:
On 12 December, world-renowned conductor Riccardo Muti performs with the Luigi Cherubini Youth Orchestra and the Choir of the Siena Cathedral “Guido Chigi Saracini” in the Vatican's Paul VI Hall. During the occasion, Muti will receive the prestigious "Ratzinger Prize," established in 2011, and awarded annually, with the Pope's approval, to eminent personalities in the field of Christian-inspired culture and art.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
On 12 December, world-renowned conductor Riccardo Muti performs with the Luigi Cherubini Youth Orchestra and the Choir of the Siena Cathedral “Guido Chigi Saracini” in the Vatican's Paul VI Hall. During the occasion, Muti will receive the prestigious "Ratzinger Prize," established in 2011, and awarded annually, with the Pope's approval, to eminent personalities in the field of Christian-inspired culture and art.

item.description: Lindsey Vonn raced to a stunning fast win in a World Cup downhill on Friday in St. Moritz, Switzerland, to earn her first victory in nearly eight years — and the first in her comeback with titanium implants in her right knee after a five-year retirement.

item.title: Gaza’s maternal and newborn health system ‘decimated’, UN warns

item.title: WHO expert group reaffirms no link between vaccines and autism
item.description: A World Health Organization (WHO) expert committee has again confirmed that there is no causal link between vaccines and autism spectrum disorders (ASD), following a new review of global scientific evidence.

item.title: Climate change supercharged cyclone damage in parts of Asia, study finds
item.description: Deadly cyclones with torrential rains are supercharged by warming temperatures, says a new report by the World Weather Attribution group. At least 1,600 people were killed after Cyclones Senyar and Ditwah tore through Malaysia, Thailand and Sri Lanka in late November.
item.source:markdown:
![Cyclone Ditwah causes flooding in Niyamgamdora, Sri Lanka, December 2 2025](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/32982fdc-bc9d-49d9-ab18-dd8ac9cbea2f,1765311172053/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C300%2C5766%2C3243%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Deadly cyclones with torrential rains are supercharged by warming temperatures, says a new report by the World Weather Attribution group. At least 1,600 people were killed after Cyclones Senyar and Ditwah tore through Malaysia, Thailand and Sri Lanka in late November.

item.title: Canon lawyers present new standard work on child welfare
item.description:
Myriam Wijlens and Yeshica Marianne Umaña Calderón release an English-language textbook on child welfare, drawing on a long-running interdisciplinary course at the University of Erfurt. The volume outlines principles of the child’s best interests in ecclesiastical and international contexts and incorporates contributions from global experts involved in child protection.

item.title: Is Trump’s stark new security strategy the end of the liberal world order? Europeans will need convincing
item.description: European leaders must decide whether to reject or embrace the conclusions of U.S. President Donald Trump’s new security strategy. item.title: U.S. plans to sell advanced AI chips to China amid economic and security concerns
item.description: In a move with major implications for national security and the race to dominate artificial intelligence, President Trump announced Monday that he will allow Nvidia to sell its H200 computer chip — an advanced chip used for developing A.I. — to China. Tufts University professor Chris Miller, author of "Chip War: The Fight for the World's Most Critical Technology," joins Geoff Bennett with more. item.title: Venezuela's Machado defies travel ban, arrives in Oslo to claim Nobel Peace Prize
item.description: After more than a year mostly spent in hiding and in defiance of a decade-long travel ban,  Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado arrived in Norway on Thursday, hours after a ceremony to award her the Nobel Peace Prize. Machado dedicated her Nobel Peace Prize to the political prisoners and human rights activists fighting for democracy in Venezuela.
item.source:markdown:
![A woman in a dress with a slight smile is shown standing behind a podium on a stage.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/e5d745ec-9f14-43ab-b179-d17843cf3146,1765380310224/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C4526%2C2545%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
After more than a year mostly spent in hiding and in defiance of a decade-long travel ban, Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado arrived in Norway on Thursday, hours after a ceremony to award her the Nobel Peace Prize. Machado dedicated her Nobel Peace Prize to the political prisoners and human rights activists fighting for democracy in Venezuela.

item.title: Architecture is art — without it ‘you're giving up’: rebel architect Frank Gehry
item.description: Toronto-born architect Frank Gehry has died at 96. This conversation is a two-part series that delves into Gehry's infusion of humanity into his designs.

item.title: Security Council LIVE: Ambassadors meet over rising civilian deaths in Ukraine
item.description: The Security Council is meeting in New York for a high-stakes briefing on Ukraine, called by six members amid rising civilian casualties and renewed strikes on energy infrastructure as winter sets in. It comes as Washington’s 28-point peace proposal is being revised following pushback from Kyiv and European allies, and after talks in Moscow and Florida failed to deliver concrete progress. Today’s meeting will gauge where diplomacy stands. Follow live below and UN News app users can click here. For in-depth meetings coverage, go here.

item.description: From salt made by hand on a Philippine island, to ceremonial dances in Kenya and ancient textile traditions in Belarus, the UN cultural agency has added a diverse range of living traditions to its global lists of culture at risk, highlighting both the richness of expression and the urgent need to safeguard heritage.

item.title: Drones during Zelensky visit 'part of threat' - minister
item.description: Minister for Justice Jim O'Callaghan has said that drones identified over Dublin Bay last week during Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky's visit were "generated for the purpose of putting pressure on EU and Ukrainian interests".
item.source:markdown: Minister for Justice Jim O'Callaghan has said that drones identified over Dublin Bay last week during Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky's visit were "generated for the purpose of putting pressure on EU and Ukrainian interests".

item.title: Sudan: UN chief condemns deadly strikes on children’s nursery, hospital
item.description: As Sudan’s civil war intensified on Monday, top UN officials condemned the killing of dozens of children in drone strikes in South Kordofan state – and the targeting of first responders trying to help the wounded.
item.source:markdown: As Sudan’s civil war intensified on Monday, top UN officials condemned the killing of dozens of children in drone strikes in South Kordofan state – and the targeting of first responders trying to help the wounded.

item.title: Humanitarians launch $33 billion appeal for 2026
item.description: The UN and partners are seeking $23 billion to provide lifesaving support next year to 87 million people worldwide affected by war, climate disasters, earthquakes, epidemics and crop failures.
item.source:markdown: The UN and partners are seeking $23 billion to provide lifesaving support next year to 87 million people worldwide affected by war, climate disasters, earthquakes, epidemics and crop failures.

item.title: UN strongly condemns Israel’s unauthorised entry of UNRWA compound in East Jerusalem
item.description: The UN agency that assists Palestine refugees, UNRWA, said that Israeli police raided its compound in East Jerusalem early on Monday, representing “a new challenge to international law.”
item.source:markdown: The UN agency that assists Palestine refugees, UNRWA, said that Israeli police raided its compound in East Jerusalem early on Monday, representing “a new challenge to international law.”

item.title: Ukraine civilians bear brunt of escalating attacks as winter closes in
item.description: Civilians across Ukraine endured a surge in deadly strikes over the weekend, with the UN warning of an “alarming pattern” of intensifying hostilities and mounting damage to essential services as temperatures continue to drop.
item.source:markdown: Civilians across Ukraine endured a surge in deadly strikes over the weekend, with the UN warning of an “alarming pattern” of intensifying hostilities and mounting damage to essential services as temperatures continue to drop.

item.title: Syria at a crossroads: UN warns fragile transition needs global support
item.description: A year after the fall of the Assad regime opened the door to political and judicial reform, Syria’s future is still precarious.
item.source:markdown: A year after the fall of the Assad regime opened the door to political and judicial reform, Syria’s future is still precarious.

item.title: At UN, OSCE warns of erosion of security principles amid Ukraine conflict
item.description: The Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) chief on Monday urged the UN Security Council to uphold core principles of sovereignty, territorial integrity and human rights, warning that Russia’s war in Ukraine continues to undermine European security.
item.source:markdown: The Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) chief on Monday urged the UN Security Council to uphold core principles of sovereignty, territorial integrity and human rights, warning that Russia’s war in Ukraine continues to undermine European security.

item.title: Global atrocity risks rising, warns new UN adviser on genocide prevention
item.description: The world is witnessing an alarming erosion of respect for international law, with conflicts increasingly targeting civilians and heightening the risk of atrocity crimes, warns the United Nations’ newly appointed Special Adviser on the Prevention of Genocide.
item.source:markdown: The world is witnessing an alarming erosion of respect for international law, with conflicts increasingly targeting civilians and heightening the risk of atrocity crimes, warns the United Nations’ newly appointed Special Adviser on the Prevention of Genocide.

item.title: Salah left out of Liverpool's Champions League squad
item.description: Mohamed Salah has been left out of Liverpool's squad for Tuesday's Champions League game at Inter Milan following on from his public outburst at the weekend.
item.source:markdown: Mohamed Salah has been left out of Liverpool's squad for Tuesday's Champions League game at Inter Milan following on from his public outburst at the weekend.

item.title: Enforced deprivation rate down for second year in a row
item.description: New figures from the Central Statistics Office show that the enforced deprivation rate decreased for the second year in a row, down to 14.8% in 2025 from 15.7% the previous year.
item.source:markdown: New figures from the Central Statistics Office show that the enforced deprivation rate decreased for the second year in a row, down to 14.8% in 2025 from 15.7% the previous year.

item.title: Toy Show Appeal tops €30m as viewers donate €4.6m

item.title: EU countries back tightening of migration rules
item.description: European Union nations have backed a significant tightening of migration rules, including allowing for "return hubs" for failed asylum-seekers to be set up outside the 27-country bloc.

item.title: Thousands of Santas dash through Liverpool streets for charity
item.description: Liverpool's annual Santa Dash made spirits bright on Sunday as thousands of runners dressed as Santa Claus took to the streets of the English city for the five-kilometre festive fun run. Participants are encouraged to raise money for local charities as part of the event, which began in 2004.

item.title: Trump's new security strategy aligns with Russia's interests, Kremlin says
item.description: The Kremlin on Sunday welcomed U.S. President Donald Trump's new national security strategy and said it largely accorded with Russia's own perceptions, the first time that Moscow has so fulsomely praised such a document from its former Cold War foe.

The Kremlin on Sunday welcomed U.S. President Donald Trump's new national security strategy and said it largely accorded with Russia's own perceptions, the first time that Moscow has so fulsomely praised such a document from its former Cold War foe.

item.title: US says deal to end Ukraine war 'really close'

item.title: ‘The system has failed’: Giles Duley’s mission to reframe disability in war
item.description: Talking to journalists earlier this week on his final day as the first UN Global Advocate for Persons with Disabilities in Conflict and Peacebuilding Situations, Giles Duley said he felt he had failed in his core mission. More importantly, he added, the system itself has failed.
item.source:markdown: Talking to journalists earlier this week on his final day as the first UN Global Advocate for Persons with Disabilities in Conflict and Peacebuilding Situations, Giles Duley said he felt he had failed in his core mission. item.title: Review after couple wrongly advised of fatal abnormality
item.description: The CEO of the HSE has issued an "unequivocal" apology on behalf of the organisation and has said an independent review will take place into the case of a couple who agreed to have a termination after being wrongly advised that their healthy baby boy had a fatal foetal abnormality.
item.source:markdown: The CEO of the HSE has issued an "unequivocal" apology on behalf of the organisation and has said an independent review will take place into the case of a couple who agreed to have a termination after being wrongly advised that their healthy baby boy had a fatal foetal abnormality.

item.title: Six years in jail for man who set fire to home in Cork
item.description: A 32-year old man who caused almost a quarter of a million euro worth of damage to three houses in Cork city after setting fire to one of them on Christmas Day two years ago has been jailed for six years and nine months.

item.title: Is Europe rearming for war with Russia? | About That
item.description: Investments are being made across Europe to shore up its defence capabilities in the face of increased Russian aggression and an uncertain defence alliance with the United States. item.title: U.S. Supreme Court to decide whether Trump's birthright citizenship order violates Constitution
item.description: The U.S. Supreme Court agreed on Friday to take up the constitutionality of President Donald Trump's order on birthright citizenship declaring that children born to parents who are in the United States illegally or temporarily are not American citizens.
item.source:markdown:
![Demonstrators holds up a banner during a citizenship rally outside of the Supreme Court.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/86078f61-2783-4f75-a806-5041c6c2c37a,1764963405043/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C420%2C5823%2C3275%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
The U.S. Supreme Court agreed on Friday to take up the constitutionality of President Donald Trump's order on birthright citizenship declaring that children born to parents who are in the United States illegally or temporarily are not American citizens.

item.title: Elon Musk's X slapped with €120M fine by EU regulator for breaching content rules
item.description: Elon Musk's social media company X was fined 120 million euros ($193.3 million Cdn) by EU tech regulators on Friday for breaching online content rules, the first sanction under landmark legislation that once again drew criticism from the U.S. government.

item.title: Four plead guilty over attempt to import drugs worth €31m

item.title: Bishops of Mozambique gather for plenary assembly in Maputo as Cardinal Parolin visits
item.description:
The Episcopal Conference of Mozambique (CEM) has said that Cardinal Pietro Parolin will visit Mozambique this week. The visit is being seen as a gesture of reassurance and closeness by the Holy Father, Pope Leo XIV, given the ongoing insurgency in the restive Cabo Delgado Province. Attacks by Islamist militants have displaced thousands and caused the deaths of many innocent civilians. CEM’s plenary assembly will also take place during this period. Cardinal Parolin is expected to be in Mozambique

Read all
item.source:markdown:
The Episcopal Conference of Mozambique (CEM) has said that Cardinal Pietro Parolin will visit Mozambique this week. The visit is being seen as a gesture of reassurance and closeness by the Holy Father, Pope Leo XIV, given the ongoing insurgency in the restive Cabo Delgado Province. Attacks by Islamist militants have displaced thousands and caused the deaths of many innocent civilians. CEM’s plenary assembly will also take place during this period. Cardinal Parolin is expected to be in Mozambique
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/africa/news/2025-12/bishops-of-mozambique-gather-for-plenary-assembly-in-maputo-as-c.html)

item.title: UN and partners back new measures to help millions move from vulnerability to opportunity
item.description: A major UN meeting in Doha wrapped up on Thursday with a renewed drive to help the world’s poorest countries move towards long-term stability and prosperity, as senior officials urged stronger global partnerships to ensure that development gains are not lost once States exit the Least Developed Country (LDC) category.

item.title: Deadly storms sweep South and Southeast Asia, leaving over 1,600 dead
item.description: From Sri Lanka’s central highlands to Indonesia’s flood-swollen river basins, a wave of climate-fuelled cyclones and monsoon rains has unleashed one of the deadliest weather patterns south and southeast Asia has seen in years, killing more than 1,600 people, displacing hundreds of thousands and affecting millions.
item.source:markdown: From Sri Lanka’s central highlands to Indonesia’s flood-swollen river basins, a wave of climate-fuelled cyclones and monsoon rains has unleashed one of the deadliest weather patterns south and southeast Asia has seen in years, killing more than 1,600 people, displacing hundreds of thousands and affecting millions.

item.title: Trade tensions temporarily on backburner as PM visits Washington for FIFA celebration
item.description: Though Prime Minister Mark Carney’s upcoming trip to the U.S. is all about FIFA soccer, it’s hard to overlook the political tensions ahead of the upcoming review of the Canada-U.S.-Mexico Agreement. If there’s an opportunity to nudge Canada-U.S. relations in a more positive direction, insiders suggest Carney should take it.
item.source:markdown:
![A man wearing a Team Canada soccer jersey, a dark jacket and a Team Canada scarf raises his fist and cheers.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/c1aaea1c-b9ab-4b76-af3e-243564ebd37d,1764818575599/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C60%2C3591%2C2019%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)

If there’s an opportunity to nudge Canada-U.S. relations in a more positive direction, insiders suggest Carney should take it.

item.title: Trump offered Putin a tactical victory in Ukraine. It wasn’t enough
item.description: The Kremlin has again rejected U.S. President Donald Trump's latest proposals to end the war in Ukraine. While Trump has tried to entice Russian President Vladimir Putin with offers of Ukrainian territory and lucrative future commercial contracts, Putin's goal of subjugating Ukraine isn't something Trump can put on the table.
item.source:markdown:
![Russian President Vladimir Putin attends a meeting with U.S. President Donald Trump's special envoy Steve Witkoff and son-in-law Jared Kushner at the Kremlin in Moscow, Russia, December 2, 2025. ](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/387cf8c5-2c8d-43a4-aaef-89d2906a504a,1764794126724/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C255%2C4786%2C2692%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
The Kremlin has again rejected U.S. President Donald Trump's latest proposals to end the war in Ukraine. While Trump has tried to entice Russian President Vladimir Putin with offers of Ukrainian territory and lucrative future commercial contracts, Putin's goal of subjugating Ukraine isn't something Trump can put on the table.

item.title: Transforming F1: How female and Gen Z fandom is shaping the sport’s future

item.title: Meta has begun shutting down kids' social media in Australia. The world is watching to see how it unfolds
item.description: As platforms like Instagram, TikTok, Snapchat and YouTube begin to comply with Australia's new landmark law banning social media for those under 16, Aussie youth are now seeing pop-ups about their accounts being deactivated or put on hold. Is there a potential for ripple effects in Canada?

![teens on cellphones](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/0770c08b-de50-4d56-8e37-4cdb9f4dadb4,1764795379022/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%28193%2C0%2C1726%2C970%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)

item.title: Cuba reconnects power grid after partial failure left Havana, much of west in dark
item.description: Cuba said it had reconnected its electrical grid and was gradually restoring power after a partial collapse on Wednesday left the capital Havana and much of western Cuba in the dark, the latest incident in an energy crisis that has left millions suffering from prolonged blackouts for months.
item.source:markdown:
![A vintage car stopped at an intersection in Havana, Cuba](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/3ed29304-897e-48e9-a46e-b5b3f34c0c24,1764796007518/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C229%2C5000%2C2812%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Cuba said it had reconnected its electrical grid and was gradually restoring power after a partial collapse on Wednesday left the capital Havana and much of western Cuba in the dark, the latest incident in an energy crisis that has left millions suffering from prolonged blackouts for months.

item.title: Syria: Hope emerges amid ongoing human rights challenges

item.title: Will a fishing boat spark a crisis between China and Japan? | About That
item.description: Tensions between China and Japan are rising over Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi's recent comments on Taiwan, combined with a long-standing dispute over a chain of uninhabited islands. Images provided by The Canadian Press, Reuters and Getty Images

item.title: Pope: ‘I was thinking of retiring, but instead I surrendered to God’
item.description:
Aboard the papal plane returning to Rome from Lebanon, Pope Leo XIV speaks to journalists about the role of the Holy See, which works “behind-the-scenes” in peace negotiations, so that all parties may lay down arms. Regarding Ukraine, the Pope underlines Europe’s involvement and the important role Italy could play, and answers a question about how he reacted to his election, stressing the importance of giving one’s life to God and letting him "lead the way".

Read all

The Prada Group closed the purchase of Milan fashion rival Versace in a $1.375 billion US ($1.93 billion Cdn) cash deal that puts the fashion house known for its sexy silhouettes under the same roof as Prada's "ugly chic" aesthetic and Miu Miu's youth-driven appeal.

item.title: Supt contacted garda about road traffic case, court told
item.description: A garda accused of perverting the course of justice by intervening in potential road traffic prosecutions told investigating officers from the Garda National Bureau of Criminal Investigation that he was contacted by a superintendent about a road traffic case, Limerick Circuit Court has heard.
item.source:markdown: A garda accused of perverting the course of justice by intervening in potential road traffic prosecutions told investigating officers from the Garda National Bureau of Criminal Investigation that he was contacted by a superintendent about a road traffic case, Limerick Circuit Court has heard.

item.title: Trump pardons drug trafficking ex-Honduran president
item.description: President Donald Trump has pardoned former Honduran President Juan Orlando Hernandez, who was released from a US prison where he was serving a 45-year sentence on drug trafficking and firearms charges.

item.title: Zimbabwe: Bishops urge national renewal, compassion, and responsible stewardship in Advent
item.description:
As the Church enters the sacred Season of Advent, Zimbabwe’s Catholic Bishops’ Conference (ZCBC) has released a Pastoral Statement titled “Advent Pastoral Message – Remember the Poor,” in which it invites Zimbabweans to use the period as a time of national renewal, both social and spiritual.

item.title: Serena Williams shuts down talk of a tennis comeback
item.description: Serena Williams threw cold water on the idea that she might be preparing to return to tennis, saying Tuesday that she is "NOT coming back," after a spokesman for the International Tennis Integrity Agency (ITIA) said the 23-time Grand Slam champion had registered with the sport's drug-testing body.
item.source:markdown:
![A women's tennis player.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/ede10cba-5c07-414c-bab8-27d870f075db,1764702087521/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C89%2C5542%2C3117%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Serena Williams threw cold water on the idea that she might be preparing to return to tennis, saying Tuesday that she is "NOT coming back," after a spokesman for the International Tennis Integrity Agency (ITIA) said the 23-time Grand Slam champion had registered with the sport's drug-testing body.

item.title: Mourners remember 'perfect' student killed in Louth crash
item.description: A Scottish student who died in a crash in Co Louth last month, in which four other people were killed, has been remembered as the "most perfect" member of her family, who was "thriving" while living abroad.

item.title: 12 officers would have faced misconduct over Hillsborough
item.description: An investigation into the 1989 Hillsborough disaster has found 12 police officers would have faced gross misconduct proceedings for "fundamental failures" on the day and "concerted efforts" to blame fans in the aftermath.

item.title: Ex-Honduran president, convicted of trafficking 360 tonnes of cocaine, out of prison after Trump pardon
item.description: Former Honduran president Juan Orlando Hernández, sentenced last year to 45 years in prison for his role in a drug-trafficking operation that moved hundreds of tonnes of cocaine to the United States, was released from prison following a pardon from President Donald Trump, officials confirmed Tuesday.
item.source:markdown:
![A man wearing sunglasses and a mask over his face is shown with hands clasped in front of him and surrounded by several people, including police officers.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/96e93b27-a152-4157-b198-239cb9cff864,1764697373102/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C5760%2C3240%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Former Honduran president Juan Orlando Hernández, sentenced last year to 45 years in prison for his role in a drug-trafficking operation that moved hundreds of tonnes of cocaine to the United States, was released from prison following a pardon from President Donald Trump, officials confirmed Tuesday.

item.title: Asia: Lives upended by cyclones, ‘extreme’ rainfall on the rise, warn UN agencies
item.description: Across southeast Asia, record-breaking rains and flooding caused by back-to-back tropical storms have claimed hundreds of lives and brought devastation and displacement upon entire communities, UN agencies said on Tuesday.
item.source:markdown: Across southeast Asia, record-breaking rains and flooding caused by back-to-back tropical storms have claimed hundreds of lives and brought devastation and displacement upon entire communities, UN agencies said on Tuesday.

item.title: Millions of jobs at risk in Asia-Pacific as AI adoption surges in wealthy nations
item.description: Millions of jobs across Asia could be at risk as the AI industry booms at the expense of poorer nations still struggling to provide basic digital access and literacy, UN economists said on Tuesday.
item.source:markdown: Millions of jobs across Asia could be at risk as the AI industry booms at the expense of poorer nations still struggling to provide basic digital access and literacy, UN economists said on Tuesday.

item.title: World News in Brief: Global economy ‘on the brink’, ending slavery, Latin America jobs update
item.description: Global economic growth will slow to 2.6 per cent in 2025, down from 2.9 per cent in 2024, as global trade and investment face growing pressure from financial volatility and geopolitical uncertainty, according to a new report by the UN Trade and Development body (UNCTAD).
item.source:markdown: Global economic growth will slow to 2.6 per cent in 2025, down from 2.9 per cent in 2024, as global trade and investment face growing pressure from financial volatility and geopolitical uncertainty, according to a new report by the UN Trade and Development body (UNCTAD).

item.title: Pope Leo at Beirut farewell: 'Choose peace as a way, not just a goal'
item.description:
Before taking off for Rome at Beirut’s airport, Pope Leo XIV concludes his Apostolic Journey to Türkiye and Lebanon, calling for dialogue, fraternity, and reconciliation across the Middle East and expressing his hope that those who “currently consider themselves enemies” may embrace a spirit of fraternity and commitment to peace.

Read all
item.source:markdown:

[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/pope/news/2025-12/pope-leo-apostolic-visit-turkiye-lebanon-farewell-ceremony-peace.html)

item.title: Pope urges Lebanese Christians to seek fraternity and peace
